sub_topic: Calculate the Killing vector fields of a metric.
message_1: Consider the metric $g = 2(dx^2 + dy^2) + 3dz^2$ on $\mathbb{R}^3$. Find all Killing vector fields of this metric.
message_2:
A Killing vector field is a vector field that generates a one-parameter group of isometries of the metric. In other words, the Lie derivative of the metric with respect to the Killing vector field must vanish. Let $X$ be a Killing vector field, then we have

$$\mathcal{L}_X g = 0$$

The Lie derivative of the metric can be expressed in terms of the covariant derivative as

$$\mathcal{L}_X g = X^i \nabla_i g_{jk} + g_{ik} \nabla_j X^i + g_{ij} \nabla_k X^i$$

Since the metric is diagonal, we have

$$g_{ij} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$$

Let $X = X^1 \partial_x + X^2 \partial_y + X^3 \partial_z$. Then the Killing equation becomes

$$X^i \nabla_i g_{jk} + g_{ik} \nabla_j X^i + g_{ij} \nabla_k X^i = 0$$

Since the metric is diagonal and constant, the first term vanishes. Thus, we have

$$g_{ik} \nabla_j X^i + g_{ij} \nabla_k X^i = 0$$

Expanding this equation, we get

$$2(\partial_j X^1, \partial_j X^2) + 3\partial_j X^3 = 0$$
$$2(\partial_k X^1, \partial_k X^2) + 3\partial_k X^3 = 0$$

These equations can be further simplified to

$$\partial_x X^1 + \partial_y X^2 = 0$$
$$\partial_x X^1 + \partial_z X^3 = 0$$
$$\partial_y X^2 + \partial_z X^3 = 0$$

Solving these equations, we find that the Killing vector fields are of the form

$$X = a \partial_x + b \partial_y + c \partial_z$$

where $a$, $b$, and $c$ are constants. Therefore, the Killing vector fields of the given metric are linear combinations of the coordinate vector fields $\partial_x$, $\partial_y$, and $\partial_z$.
